data.title: Understanding the XAF and CFA: A Guide to Cameroon's Currencies
data.meta_description: The Central African CFA franc (CFA) and the Central African CFA franc (XAF) are the primary currencies used in Cameroon.
data.text:
Looking to send money back home to Cameroon? Understanding the country's currencies is essential. The Central African CFA franc (CFA) and the Central African CFA franc (XAF) are the primary currencies used in Cameroon. Let's explore the history and use cases of these currencies.

The Central African CFA Franc (CFA)

â

The Central African CFA Franc (CFA): The Central African CFA franc (CFA) is a common currency used by six countries in Central Africa, including Cameroon. These countries are Cameroon, Chad, the Central African Republic, the Republic of the Congo, Equatorial Guinea, and Gabon.

Introduced in 1945, the CFA franc was initially tied to the French franc and later pegged to the euro. The CFA is issued by the Bank of Central African States (BEAC) and serves as a stable currency for trade and economic transactions in the region.

The Central African CFA Franc (XAF)

â

The Central African CFA franc (XAF) is the specific variant of the CFA used in Cameroon. It is denoted by the currency code XAF and is further divided into smaller units called centimes. The XAF is widely accepted in Cameroon and is used for everyday transactions, including buying goods and services, paying bills, and remittances.

Historical Background

â

The adoption of the CFA franc in Cameroon dates back to the colonial era when the country was under French rule. The currency offered stability and facilitated economic ties with other French-speaking African countries. Today, the CFA franc continues to play a crucial role in Cameroon's economy as a means of exchange and a store of value.

Use cases and benefits:

â

The XAF offers numerous advantages for immigrants sending money to Cameroon. Firstly, it provides a familiar and widely accepted currency for recipients, ensuring ease of use and accessibility. Additionally, the stability of the CFA franc helps preserve the value of remittances, allowing families to maintain their purchasing power over time.
